column4: HuffPost//The portraits of former Presidents Bill Clinton and George Bush have been restored to their former prominent place in the White House after they were sidelined during the presidency of Donald Trump

column3: who grew up in the segregated South to become an influential leader in the American civil rights movement
column4: Washington politics and Wall Street
column5: has died at age 85

column7: who grew up in the segregated South to become an influential leader in the American civil rights movement
column8: Washington politics and Wall Street
column9: has died at age 85
column10: his daughter said on Tuesday.//Jordan
column11: who in 1980 was badly wounded by a white supremacist sniper in Indiana

column13: â€ daughter Vickee Jordan said in a statement.//His role as a Washington insider took him all the way to the White House
column14: where he was a close friend

column16: but no one knew better than Jordan how favors
column17: access and requests worked in Washington.//In a statement
column22: â€œVernon Jordan brought his big brain and strong heart to everything and everybody he touched.â€ Clinton mentioned Jordanâ€™s instrumental role in desegregating the University of Georgia in 1961
column23: his career in law and business
column24: and his work with civil rights groups.//Jordan grew up in a housing project in Atlanta before his family bought a home and he was the only Black person in his class at DePauw University in rural Greencastle
column26: Jordan earned a law degree from Howard University and returned to Atlanta to work for a civil rights attorney. Among his cases was one that integrated the University of Georgia at a time of racial segregation in Southern states. Jordan helped escort his two young Black clients past jeering protesters on their first day of class.//Jordan later went to work for the NAACP and the United Negro College Fund before becoming head of the National Urban League in 1971. He worked well into his 80s
column27: going back and forth between the jobs at the Akin Gump international law and lobbying firm in Washington and the Lazard financial management firm in New York.//â€œTo the world
column28: Vernon was a towering civil rights figure
column30: and a counselor to CEOs and governments around the globe. And he was all of those things. But to those of us at Akin Gump
column31: Vernon was also a wise and trusted mentor and friend
column32: â€ the firm said in a statement.//â€œHis achievements were doubly remarkable considering the obstacles he overcame as a Black man rising from the virulent racism of Americaâ€™s segregated Deep South. Vernon burned brighter than the rest of us
column33: with a vitality amplified by his imposing frame and resonant voice
column34: â€ Lazard Chairman and CEO Kenneth Jacobs wrote in a memo to employees.//After gains in voting rights and equal access laws
column35: Jordanâ€™s approach was to push for greater economic opportunities for Black people
column36: even in corporate boardrooms.//At an Urban League event Jordan said he told the organizationâ€™s corporate benefactors
column37: â€œDonâ€™t just give us money and donâ€™t just show up for the Equal Opportunity Day dinner. That is not enough when you look at Black consumer power in this country. Itâ€™s not enough for you to come and shake our hands and be our friends. We want in.â€//Under his leadership
column38: the Urban League began issuing its annual State of Black America reports to assess the social and economic status of Black Americans.//U.S. companies such as American Express
column43: Revlon and Sara Lee put him on their boards
column44: where he was often the only Black member.//Jordan was close to President Jimmy Carter in the 1970s
column45: and Carter reportedly offered him cabinet jobs. Jordan would eventually become critical of Carter
column46: saying he had not delivered on his economic promises to Blacks.//In 1980
column47: Jordan was badly wounded as he exited the car of a white woman who was an Urban League member in Fort Wayne
column49: a former Ku Klux Klansman and member of the American Nazi Party who was convicted of a series of race-related murders
column50: admitted to the ambush but was acquitted. He told authorities he hated interracial couples.//After 10 years at the Urban League
column51: Jordan wanted something different and joined Akin Gump. Tall and imposing
column52: he earned a reputation for being a charming and persuasive â€œWashington wise man.â€ After Clinton was elected president in 1992
column54: whom he had known since the early 1970s
column55: to head his transition team.//In 2008 when Barack Obama was running to be the first Black president
column56: Jordan stuck by his longtime friends and supported Hillary Clinton for the Democratic Partyâ€™s nomination. According to the Financial Times
column58: â€œI am too old to trade friendship for race.â€//Jordanâ€™s first wife
column60: died of multiple sclerosis in 1985. They had one child. In 1986 he married Ann Dibble.//Additional reporting by Susan Heavey and Will Dunham; Writing by Bill Trott; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama and Steve Orlofsky"
